Authors:
Anna Maria Fiore-Donno, Edward F. Haskins, J. Pawlowski,
Tom Cavalier-Smith
Title:
Semimorula liquescens is a modified echinostelid myxomycete
(Mycetozoa)
Abstract:
The enigmatic Semimorula liquescens E.F. Haskins, McGuin.
& C.S. Berry has been isolated repeatedly from dried infructescences
of Lythrum salicaria collected from Seattle and Kirkland, Washington.
Detailed developmental, morphological and ultrastructural studies
suggested that it represents a taxon within Mycetozoa, closely allied
with Myxogastria (Myxomycetes), but with unique characteristics.
Phylogeny based on two genes places it with confidence into the family
Echinosteliidae. This species differs from a typical Echinostelium in
the way spores germinate and in the lack of a stalked sporophore, the
latter being a secondary loss. Semimorula liquescens may therefore be a
useful “negative” model to search for genes inducing stalk formation
during sporulation.
